question.text: An ideal gas is expanded from <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>)</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi>to</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></math> under different conditions. The correct statement(s) among the following is(are)

options.text: The work done on the gas is maximum when it is compressed irreversibly from ( <math><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mi> </mi><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></math> to <math><mo>(</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mi> </mi><mi> </mi><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></math> against constant pressure <math><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></math>
If the expansion is carried out freely, it is simultaneously both isothermal as well as adiabatic

The work done on the gas is less when it is expanded reversibly from <math><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mi> </mi><mi>t</mi><mi>o</mi><mi> </mi><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> under adiabatic conditions as compared to that when expanded reversibly from <math><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mi> </mi><mi>t</mi><mi>o</mi><mi> </mi><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> under isothermal conditions.

The change in internal energy of the gas (i) zero, if it is expanded reversibly with  <math><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mi> </mi><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>  , and (ii) positive, if it is expanded reversibly under adiabatic conditions with  <math><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mi> </mi><mo>≠</mo><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>
